title: What happens if someone dies in space? A NASA astronaut reveals the rules they have to follow - The Economic Times
summary:
What happens if someone dies in space? A NASA astronaut reveals the rules they have to follow

Date: January 11, 2025
Source: The Feed

A NASA astronaut must be prepared for various scenarios, including the unfortunate event of a death in space. This article sheds light on the protocols NASA follows in such situations and highlights the importance of training for astronauts.

  • A NASA astronaut must follow specific protocols if a colleague dies in space.
  • Chris Hadfield explains the necessity of 'death simulations' that are part of astronaut training.
  • If death occurs during an EVA, the body must be brought into the airlock and kept in a pressurized suit.
  • The body is stored away to prevent odor from decomposition affecting the rest of the crew.
“Are NASA astronauts trained for death in space? Yes, NASA astronauts are trained on what to do if a death occurs in space, and the related activities surrounding it.”

This preparation underscores NASA's commitment to ensuring the safety and well-being of its astronauts, even in the most dire situations.
newTitle: What Happens If Someone Dies in Space? A NASA Astronaut Reveals the Protocols

title: Rush to the space: Exploration of other celestial bodies for natural resources is on - The Financial Express
Smart farming: AI predicts potato growth potential, marking the beginning of ‘a new era in farming’ - Potato News Today
summary:
Smart farming: AI predicts potato growth potential, marking the beginning of ‘a new era in farming’

Publication Date: 27 December 2024 | Source: Utrecht University

A cutting-edge AI tool developed by biologists from Utrecht University aims to revolutionize potato farming by predicting how well seed potatoes will grow into healthy plants using DNA data and drone imaging.

  • The AI model was created through collaboration between Utrecht University, TU Delft, and plant breeders.
  • This research explores the relationship between microbes on seed potatoes and plant growth.
  • The team confirmed that specific bacteria and fungi play a crucial role in potato growth.
  • Gathering data from 240 test fields helped uncover patterns that connect microbial presence to yield and health.
“For the first time, we can predict the quality of seed potatoes based on their microbial makeup,” said Dr. Roeland Berendsen.

The findings suggest that understanding microbial influence can lead to healthier crops, improved yields, and more sustainable agriculture practices.
newTitle: AI Revolutionizes Potato Farming by Predicting Growth Potential

title: 2025 night sky events: Eclipses, supermoons, and celestial spectacles await - India Today
summary:
2025 Night Sky Events: Eclipses, Supermoons, and More Await Stargazers

Published On: Jan 12, 2025
Source: indiatodayglobal

Skywatchers in 2025 are in for a treat as they will have the privilege of witnessing a series of rare celestial events – from breathtaking meteor showers to a once-in-a-lifetime annular solar eclipse visible across parts of the US.

Key Points

  • Eclipses: Total lunar eclipse on March 14, followed by a partial solar eclipse two weeks later.
  • Another total lunar eclipse in September, with another partial solar eclipse soon after.
  • Supermoons: Three supermoons in October, November, and December, with November’s being the closest to Earth.
  • Planet Parade: Six planets aligning in mid-January, visible after sunset.
  • Northern and Southern Lights: Increased geomagnetic storms expected, offering more chances to see auroras.
  • Meteor Showers: Major showers like the Perseids and Geminids in August and December, alongside lesser-known showers throughout the year.

Conclusion

2025 promises to be a vibrant year for skywatching, filled with various celestial phenomena that will fascinate both avid astronomers and casual observers alike.
newTitle: 2025 Night Sky Events: Eclipses, Supermoons, and More Await Stargazers

title: Detection of Thioacetaldehyde (CH3CHS) in TMC-1: Sulfur-oxygen Differentiation Along The Hydrogenation Sequence - Astrobiology News
summary:
Detection of Thioacetaldehyde (CH3CHS) in TMC-1: Sulfur-Oxygen Differentiation Along The Hydrogenation Sequence

Publication Date: Accepted for publication in A&A Letters

Source: Astrobiology

In recent years the chemistry of sulfur in the interstellar medium has experienced a renewed interest due to the detection of a large variety of molecules containing sulfur. This article reports the first identification in space of thioacetaldehyde (CH3CHS), which is the sulfur counterpart of acetaldehyde (CH3CHO).

  • Seven individual lines were detected corresponding to the rotational transitions of CH3CHS in the Q band (31.0-50.3 GHz).
  • Assuming a rotational temperature of 9 K, a column density of 9.8e10 cm-2 for CH3CHS was derived.
  • CH3CHS is 36 times less abundant than its oxygen counterpart CH3CHO.
  • Hydrogenation seems to be less favored for S-bearing molecules compared to O-bearing ones in cold sources like TMC-1.
  • The chemical model used underestimates the observed abundance of thioacetaldehyde.
By comparing the column densities of the O- and S-bearing molecules detected in TMC-1, it was found that as these molecules increase their degree of hydrogenation, sulfur-bearing molecules become less abundant.

This discovery highlights the complexities of astrochemical processes in space, particularly how sulfur and oxygen-bearing molecules behave differently in the interstellar medium.
newTitle: Detection of Thioacetaldehyde (CH3CHS) in TMC-1: Sulfur-Oxygen Differentiation Along The Hydrogenation Sequence

title: What can dark energy teach us about the hidden world of dark data? - The Brighter Side of News
Amateur Astronomer Discovers Unexpected Composition of Jupiter’s Clouds - Gadgets 360
summary:
Amateur Astronomer Discovers Unexpected Composition of Jupiter’s Clouds

Publication Date: October 30, 2023 | Source: Gadgets 360

An amateur astronomer, Steve Hill, has challenged the previous understanding of Jupiter's atmospheric composition by observing that the planet's clouds may not contain ammonia ice, as was previously believed. The findings are based on data collected using commercial telescopes.

  • Jupiter's clouds are potentially composed of ammonium hydrosulfide rather than ammonia ice.
  • The observations used a method called band-depth analysis to measure atmospheric gas levels.
  • The study has implications for understanding photochemical processes affecting gas giant atmospheres.
  • Collaborative efforts between amateur and professional astronomers can lead to significant discoveries.
“The main reflection appears to stem from ammonium hydrosulfide clouds or photochemical products rather than pure ammonia ice.” - Patrick Irwin, Planetary Physicist

The discovery opens new avenues for research into the atmospheric dynamics of gas giants and may require adjustments to existing models of Jupiter's atmosphere.
newTitle: Amateur Astronomer Discovers Unexpected Composition of Jupiter’s Clouds

title: New Cartilage Type Found: Lipocartilage Resembles Fat, Boosts Elasticity - Gadgets 360
summary:
New Cartilage Type Found: Lipocartilage Resembles Fat, Boosts Elasticity

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: Gadgets 360

Scientists have identified a new form of cartilage called lipocartilage, which is characterized by a unique structure that includes balloon-like cells filled with oils. This tissue offers enhanced elasticity and is found in areas such as the ear and nose.

Key Points

  • Lipocartilage is distinct from the three commonly recognized types of cartilage.
  • The tissue's structure allows it to maintain size regardless of calorie intake.
  • Maksim Plikus described lipocartilage's role in ear acoustics.
  • This form of cartilage may require updates to existing anatomical texts.

Notable Quotes or Statistics

“It's like Bubble Wrap,” – Maksim Plikus, Professor at the University of California, Irvine.

Conclusion

The discovery of lipocartilage suggests a potential reclassification of cartilage types and calls for further research into its evolutionary and functional implications.
newTitle: New Cartilage Type Found: Lipocartilage Resembles Fat, Boosts Elasticity

title: Astronomers Discover Water and Carbon Dioxide in WASP-166 b's Atmosphere - Gadgets 360
Human Hunting More Responsible for Kangaroo Extinction than Climate Change - Gadgets 360
summary:
Human Hunting More Responsible for Kangaroo Extinction than Climate Change

Publication Date: January 9, 2025

Source: NPR

The extinction of many kangaroo species in Australia may have been more directly linked to human activities rather than climatic changes. This conclusion is drawn from fossil evidence indicating that kangaroos had adaptable diets, suggesting human hunting played a critical role in their extinction.

  • The study analyzed 937 kangaroo teeth specimens, revealing varied diets that contradict previous beliefs about their vulnerability to climate change.
  • The timing of human arrival in Australia coincides with the decline of kangaroo populations, strengthening the argument that hunting was a major factor.
  • Future research leveraging similar dental analyses could lend insights into the dietary habits of other extinct species and their extinction causes.
“The evidence suggests these animals had varied diets, making them more resilient to environmental changes.”

This study posits that human impacts may have overshadowed environmental factors in driving kangaroo extinction, prompting a re-evaluation of the causes of past megafaunal extinctions.
newTitle: Human Hunting More Responsible for Kangaroo Extinction than Climate Change

title: Astronauts Gear Up for Daring Spacewalks and Breakthrough Science on the ISS - SciTechDaily
summary:
Astronauts Gear Up for Daring Spacewalks and Breakthrough Science on the ISS

Publication Date: Not specified Source: SciTechDaily

The Expedition 72 crew aboard the International Space Station (ISS) is preparing for spacewalks aimed at servicing scientific equipment and conducting significant research. These efforts will enhance the ISS’s capabilities while investigating the potential for microbial life in space.

  • Two upcoming spacewalks are scheduled for January 16 and January 23.
  • The first involves astronauts Nick Hague and Suni Williams focusing on multiple repairs and equipment upgrades over approximately six and a half hours.
  • The second spacewalk will include tasks related to replacing an antenna assembly and microbial searches, with astronauts yet to be confirmed.
“Working in partnership, we continue to expand our knowledge and capabilities in space.” - NASA Official

These missions not only maintain the ISS but also contribute to ongoing research that supports human health in space and on Earth.
newTitle: Astronauts Prepare for Upcoming Spacewalks and Important Experiments on ISS

title: Pluto and Charon formed through a 'kiss and capture' collision - Earth.com
summary:
Pluto and Charon Formed Through a Unique 'Kiss and Capture' Collision

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Earth.com

Billions of years ago, two celestial bodies collided in the solar system, leading to the formation of Pluto and its moon, Charon, through a process referred to as 'kiss and capture'. A recent study from the University of Arizona challenges previous theories regarding their formation.

  • The study challenges previous assumptions about how Pluto and Charon were formed.
  • Researchers discovered that the materials in these bodies behave differently than previously thought, resulting in a 'kiss and capture' scenario.
  • The collision preserved the integrity of Pluto and Charon, contradicting older models of planetary formation.
  • Tidal forces from the collision may have led to the development of a subsurface ocean on Pluto.
  • This research has implications for understanding planetary formation and could apply to other celestial bodies.
“Most planetary collision scenarios are classified as ‘hit and run’ or ‘graze and merge.’ What we’ve discovered is something entirely different – a ‘kiss and capture’ scenario.” - Adeene Denton

This discovery reshapes theories of planetary system formation and highlights new processes that govern the evolution of celestial bodies.
newTitle: Pluto and Charon Formed Through a Unique 'Kiss and Capture' Collision

Scientists learn how energetic particles affect plasma edge stability - Tech Explorist
NASA pursuing two strategies for returning Mars samples - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA Aims to Return the Samples in the 2030s

Publication Date: New Delhi

NASA has changed its approach for returning the samples collected by the Perseverance Rover to maximize the success of the attempt. The rover has stashed one copy of the collected samples in a depot and carries the other with it.

  • NASA will pursue two different strategic plans for formulating the return program, with confirmation expected by the second half of 2026.
  • Perseverance is now tasked with delivering the samples to the lander instead of having a retrieval rover.
  • NASA is exploring two options for delivering the lander: the sky crane method and utilizing novel commercial capabilities.
  • A nuclear power source will be used instead of solar panels to simplify the mission.
  • The Mars Ascent Vehicle (MAV) is expected to execute the first rocket launch from the surface of Mars.
"The financial viability of the complex mission has been questioned by auditors."

In summary, NASA is collaborating with ESA for the Mars sample return mission, aiming for a streamlined approach to successfully bring Mars samples back to Earth.
newTitle: NASA Pursues Two Strategies for Mars Sample Return

title: Comet Atlas C/2024 G3: A Celestial Event to Witness - The Munich Eye
summary:
Prepare for the Spectacle of Comet Atlas C/2024 G3 in 2025

Date: Sat 11th Jan, 2025

Following the recent Quadrantids meteor shower, skywatchers will soon be treated to another dazzling celestial event: the arrival of comet Atlas C/2024 G3. This comet is set to reach its perihelion, the point in its orbit where it comes closest to the sun, on January 13, 2025. Coincidentally, it will also be at its nearest point to Earth on the same date, making it a potential candidate for the title of the brightest comet of the year. With no other comets expected to be visible to the naked eye in 2025, this event is one not to be missed.

  • Discovered on April 5, 2024, by the Asteroid Terrestrial-Impact Last Alert System (Atlas).
  • Comet C/2024 G3 comes from the Oort Cloud, a distant region at the fringes of our solar system.
  • Set to be approximately 13.5 million kilometers from the sun at perihelion.
  • Could achieve a brightness of magnitude -4.5, similar to Venus, and likely visible to the naked eye in the southern hemisphere.
  • Its structural integrity is a concern due to the intense heat it will experience near the sun.
  • Visible just after sunset on January 13, 2025, in the southern hemisphere.
  • Experts advise caution when attempting to observe the comet, particularly in regard to viewing conditions and safety precautions.
Experts recommend that only experienced astronomers attempt to view C/2024 G3, as looking directly at the sun without appropriate filters can result in serious eye damage.

For those in the northern hemisphere, viewing conditions will be challenging, and the use of binoculars or telescopes may enhance the experience for southern observers.
newTitle: Comet Atlas C/2024 G3: A Celestial Event to Witness

title: Iron lines in the X-ray detected from a binary black hole system - Tech Explorist
Europe’s NewAthena to be largest X-ray observatory ever - News9 LIVE
summary:
Europe’s NewAthena to be largest X-ray observatory ever

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

The European Space Agency (ESA) has started the initial study phase for a new flagship X-ray observatory, named NewAthena. Planned for a launch in 2037, it aims to explore the X-ray universe with unprecedented accuracy.

  • Originally proposed as the Athena mission in 2014, it has been renamed to NewAthena.
  • Construction is set to begin in 2027, with a launch using the Ariane 6 rocket planned for 2037.
  • NewAthena will be the largest X-ray observatory ever built.
  • The observatory will investigate galaxies, supernovae, and black holes, providing deep insights into unsolved astrophysics questions.
  • It can identify bright black holes and map the hot gas between galaxies.
“NewAthena will help probe some of the pressing unresolved questions in astrophysics.”

This project is expected to significantly enhance our understanding of the universe's dynamics. The collaboration with gravitational wave observatories aims to deepen insights into the cosmos.
newTitle: Europe’s NewAthena to be largest X-ray observatory ever

title: Revealing the 'true colors' of a single-atom layer of metal alloys - Nanowerk
Sunita Williams To Go On Her First Spacewalk In 12 Years - NDTV
summary:
Sunita Williams To Go On Her First Spacewalk In 12 Years

Publication Date: January 8, 2025

Source: NASA

Sunita Williams is set to undertake her first spacewalk in 12 years, joining fellow astronaut Nick Hague aboard the International Space Station on January 16 to repair the NICER X-ray telescope.

  • Williams will participate in two spacewalks on January 16 and January 23.
  • The January 16 mission will involve replacing a rate gyro assembly and repairing the NICER telescope.
  • The January 23 mission will focus on removing an antenna and testing for microbial life on the ISS exterior.
  • This will be Williams' eighth spacewalk and Hague's fourth.
“On January 16, NASA astronauts Nick Hague and Suni Williams will exit the space station to repair the NICER X-ray telescope.” — International Space Station

These spacewalks are part of NASA's ongoing efforts to maintain and upgrade the International Space Station.
newTitle: Sunita Williams To Go On Her First Spacewalk In 12 Years

title: Planetary Parade: A Celestial Spectacle for Stargazers in India and Odisha - OTV News
summary:
Planetary Parade: Celestial spectacle for stargazers in India and Odisha

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: OTV News

Astronomy enthusiasts across India are gearing up for a celestial treat with a rare planetary parade visible to the naked eye. This event promises a breathtaking alignment of major planets in the evening sky.

  • The planetary alignment peaks on January 18, featuring Venus and Saturn closely aligned.
  • The event is visible until around 20:30 on that date.
  • Apart from Venus and Saturn, other planets may also be observed throughout the month.
  • The phenomenon encourages public engagement and educational opportunities in astronomy.
  • Optimal viewing conditions are suggested away from urban light pollution.
“Such planetary alignments are infrequent, making them a highly anticipated event for astronomy aficionados.”

This planetary parade offers a unique experience for both amateur astronomers and the general public, fostering interest and education in astronomy.
newTitle: Celestial Parade: Stunning Planetary Alignment in India's Night Sky

7 Unseen Images Of Black Holes And Outer Space Captured By NASA - Times Now
summary:
7 Unseen Images Of Black Holes And Outer Space Captured By NASA

Date: Jan 11, 2025 | Source: Times Now

This article highlights seven incredible images captured by NASA, showcasing various celestial phenomena and new discoveries related to black holes and outer space.

  • The Black Hole Let Out Two Burps: Observations of a supermassive black hole releasing bubbles of hot gas, located 900 million light-years away.
  • Discovering Protostellar OH 339.88-1.26: This image shows dark dust lanes and bright stars in a region 8900 light-years away.
  • Supermassive Black Hole Seed: An illustration depicting potential origins for supermassive black holes revealed by three space telescopes.
  • Young Star HH-47: Image showing a star concealed within a dust cloud near its companion star.
  • The Double Black Hole: Artistic portrayal of a binary black hole in the closest quasar to Earth, Markarian 231.
  • AFGL 5180: A stunning image of star-forming clouds, hinting at the origins of our solar system.
  • NGC 5548: A galaxy with a supermassive black hole at its core, showing turbulent gas flow obstructing X-ray emissions.
“These images provide profound insights into the universe and the complex behaviors of black holes.”

The captured images illustrate NASA's ongoing contributions to our understanding of the universe, highlighting both stunning visuals and significant scientific insights.
newTitle: NASA Captures Stunning Images of Black Holes and Outer Space

title: Asteroid Alert! Big Space Rock To Approach Earth Tomorrow At 30781 KMPH, NASA Warns - Times Now
summary:
Asteroid Alert! Big Space Rock To Approach Earth Tomorrow At 30781 KMPH, NASA Warns

Date: January 11, 2025 | Source: Times Now

A house-sized asteroid, designated 2024 YZ12, is set to make a close approach to Earth tomorrow, January 12, 2025, traveling at a speed of 30,781 km/h.

  • The asteroid measures approximately 56 feet in diameter.
  • It will make its closest approach at 2:14 PM IST, passing at a safe distance of 1,210,000 kilometers from Earth.
  • NASA assures that 2024 YZ12 poses no threat, providing a valuable opportunity for scientific study.
  • Monitoring near-Earth objects like asteroids helps improve predictive models essential for understanding potential risks.
“History has shown the destructive power of asteroid impacts, such as the one that caused the mass extinction event 66 million years ago.”

The flyby of 2024 YZ12 emphasizes the need for continuous monitoring of asteroids to safeguard our planet from potential threats.
newTitle: Asteroid Alert! House-Sized Asteroid to Safely Pass Earth at 30781 KMPH

title: It's Time for Sustainable Development Goal for Space - Universe Today
summary:
It's Time for Sustainable Development Goal for Space

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] Source: [Insert Source Here]

This article discusses the call for an 18th Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) focused on space, emphasizing the need for sustainable practices in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) to mitigate the growing issue of space debris.

  • The United Nations' 2030 Agenda calls for global action to protect the planet, with considerations for space.
  • A recent study suggests the importance of adopting SDG18 for the sustainable use of Earth's orbit.
  • Space debris poses significant hazards to operational satellites, with over 40,500 pieces larger than 10 cm currently in LEO.
  • Experts advocate for a legal framework similar to marine debris laws to address the space debris problem.
  • Quotes from researchers underscore the urgency of protecting space as a finite resource.

“The need to protect and connect our natural environments...has never been more urgent.” - Dr. Imogen Ellen Napper

In conclusion, adopting an SDG for space could be pivotal for ensuring sustainable practices in space exploration and utilization, aiming to protect orbital pathways for future generations.
newTitle: It's Time for Sustainable Development Goal for Space

title: 7 mind-blowing 'astronomy picture of the day' by NASA - DNA India
summary:
7 Mind-Blowing Astronomy Pictures of the Day by NASA

Date: Jan 11, 2025

Source: DNA

This article showcases seven remarkable astronomy pictures of the day captured by NASA, highlighting the beauty and mystery of the universe.

  • An unassuming region in the constellation Taurus holds dark and dusty nebulae.
  • In the future, only one of two colliding galaxies will remain.
  • The closest star system to the Sun is the Alpha Centauri system.
  • M27: The Dumbbell Nebula is featured.
